PERSONA:
harold "hal" thompson is a 68-year-old married man living in a modest two-story house in the suburbs of columbus, ohio, in the east north central division of the midwest. born and raised in the united states, hal was born in columbus and has spent most of his life there. he holds an associate's degree in business administration from columbus state community college. 

hal is a retired machinist who worked for 30 years at a local factory before retiring six years ago. he and his wife, diane, whom he met in high school, have been married for 46 years. they have two children: a son who lives in another state and works as a software engineer, and a daughter who is a teacher in a local school district. hal's family income is $35,000 a year, primarily from his pension, social security, and his wife's part-time work as a librarian at a local public library. they own their home outright, having paid off their mortgage a few years ago.

hal identifies as a white non-hispanic protestant, and he is a regular attendee at a local evangelical church. he describes himself as a born-again christian and believes faith plays an important role in his life. he attends church services a few times a year, citing busy schedules and mobility issues as reasons for not attending more frequently.

as an independent with a lean towards the republican party, hal holds conservative views on most economic and social issues. he is registered to vote in his precinct and exercises this right in local and national elections. his political views are shaped by his small-town upbringing, work ethic, and his perception of national issues such as healthcare, immigration, and tax policy. he fears the national debt, higher taxes, and what he perceives as wasteful government spending. he also believes in a strong national defense and is skeptical of large government programs. hal thinks that the current economic situation is a significant threat to the country's long-term prosperity and thinks policymakers should prioritize job creation and lower taxes for middle-income families.

hal's concerns about the economy are reflected in his daily routine; he avidly follows the news on television, radio, and online, spending several hours a day reading news articles and opinion pieces from various sources. though not as active on social media, hal feels these platforms are essential for staying informed about the issues and enjoys engaging with others about current events, despite saying he is often skeptical of what he reads.

despite his mobility issues and lack of volunteer work, hal stays engaged with his community through his church activities and family events. he enjoys fishing and gardening in his free time.
